Comments_List: n/a--project-based course
climate and energy policy analysis
Furthered my understanding in the state of climate adaptation implementation in the US.

This was a client based course, so we got to work on a bunch of different issues throughout the semester and really hone in on electric vehicles. It was a great experience, learned about research and political advocacy and other efforts.
Learned about my client organization.
Learned a lot about the technical, regulatory, economic, and social implications of bringing the offshore wind industry to California. Enhanced my data analysis skills.

This was a clinic course and so was designed to give students the opportunity to do interesting work with a client and to develop time management skills and consulting practice. I think this class did a very good job at achieving that goal.

I learned a lot about the client project I selected, on just transition initiatives to help communities impacted by coal retirements in creating new economic and employment opportunities. I also gained experience working with external clients, which I feel is a valuable skill for professionally-oriented grad students. Dan additionally brought in a few great guest lecturers, who provided interesting insights into current climate & energy topics including New Jersey's clean energy policy initiatives.
It is a client course so engaging with the client, setting expectations, and developing a meaningful deliverable are all parts of the skill building for the class.
Real world professional experiences in energy policy advocacy

- Managing a project with a client 
- Project-specific knowledge related to energy policy
Better understanding of how distributed energy resources might participate in wholesale power markets.
I learned a lot about energy issues in areas I didn't get a chance to research before.
Great!
very well
Very well aligned. Both the instructor and client provided valuable resources to enhance my learning.
I would say it did for the most part. It built off of other courses like Energy Policy in Practice and Energy Economics. I would say that there isn't a ton of new things coming from it.
Yes.
They aligned well.
Fairly well -- I knew this was going to be a client-based class, and through the project selection process had a pretty good idea of what I would gain from doing the work.
The projects are very different from one another.  My project matched the description of it (provided during shopping period) but was not what I expected before the class began.
I had a learning experience that was very closely aligned with what I was expected, and this course set me up nicely for several job interviews.
Met expectations
Mixed - would have liked a better understanding of my client's strategies for engaging with stakeholders on their advocacy efforts.

I worked on a environmental topic I didn't work on before so I definitely gained new insights. I would have liked to get more feedback on the focus of my research so I wouldn't have to cover so much ground and instead focus on a few key issues for the client.
n/a

Good spread of projects. The instructor has done a good job on vetting clients and setting expectations. I really enjoyed the guest speakers that were brought in and would love to learn more about Dan's journey in climate and energy policy and where he sees the future of the field heading.
The clients were really great. I'd say as long as good clients and partners come to the course, it will be successful. Dan is a great facilitator.
It was pretty good all around.

Strengths: Utech's class structure enabled students to really dive into their projects, instead of doing busy work for the class. I really liked the guest speakers that Utech brought in. 

Weaknesses: there could have been slightly more structure early on in the semester, in terms of connecting with our clients and creating a project proposal.

I think the course was designed really well. Dan made himself available to use if we needed anything and the projects that were selected for the course were well designed. I really enjoyed working with my client and interacting with Dan. The speakers that we had throughout the semester were also wonderful!

Strengths: external client-based projects are relevant and impactful in the real world, which I appreciate, and the client/project opportunities were well laid out

Weaknesses: Dan Utech could have been a bit more available/present throughout the semester -- most of the time we didn't actually meet for class, so the course was pretty unstructured, with just a few check-ins with Dan throughout the spring; this was mostly compensated for by regular check-ins with our client, but Dan could have imposed a bit more structure to the course.

It is a good class with good guest lectures and client projects.  Ultimately finding more ways to provide feedback and push students to produce the best possible products is an area for further improvement.
It is very useful if you have a good client, which I did. I think there could have been a bit more lectures around how effective policy advocacy and development is carried out.

I thought this was a well-structured project course. I appreciated having the structure, deadlines, and support from Dan when needed, and I thought it helped to have pre-set expectations with our clients that were set by Dan/the course. I thought that the list of project topics were good and I enjoyed having the opportunity to dig into a specific policy area for a set amount of time. I think that if what you want is basically a more formal, structured independent study, then this class is a good choice. I also liked the guest lectures we had, especially Kathleen Frangione (chief policy advisor for Gov. Murphy of NJ).
Good projects in theory, but client was too hands off.
I think there need to be a balance between projects that are actually for 2 or more people and projects that are for one person.
Pay careful attention to the scope of the project you are working on, especially if you are the sole individual assigned to the project
Take this your second year for the Capstone but also after you've wrapped up many aspects of your energy education. It will involve you doing a lot of heavy lifting, so it's not an easy pursuit.
Find a good client project.

Would recommend taking the course, but be sure you are really interested in the project you are chosen to work on (and the client you are chosen to work with) . I don't think everyone in the class had as positive an experience as my group did.
This is a great clinic. Dan does a really good job selecting projects and bringing in interesting speakers.

Take it if you find a project that is interesting (and given Dan's connections in the climate policy world, chances of that are high), but not if you're looking for a high level of engagement from the instructor. Maureen Burke's Business & Environment Consulting Clinic is a better fit for those looking for more feedback from the professor.
It is a high workload class but can be very satisfying if you identify and engage with a project you are interested in.
Have a sense of what issues you want to do a project on.

If you want to dig into a policy/project area in climate or renewable energy in a self-directed way and get some experience with client work, this is a great class for you! If you feel like you still need to deepen your technical knowledge of a subject area, you may need to look elsewhere first.
Make sure you get an engaged client (hard to predict!)

I think it would be helpful to talk about limits to the research more. My reaserch was very broad to begin with in comparison to the other projects in the class and I didn't get any feedback from my client on narrowing the scope so I tried to cover too much which eventually hurt my final outcome.
